image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives About this object

profileText: A Representative from Georgia; born in Palmer, Hampden County, Mass., August 27, 1800; received private instructions and also attended Westfield Academy; read law with his brother at Allentown, Pa.; was admitted to the bar in Philadelphia in 1822 and commenced practice in Waynesville, Ga., in 1823; settled on St. Simons Island, Ga., in 1826 and engaged in agricultural pursuits; also interested in canal and railroad projects; member of the State senate in 1832, 1834, 1835, and 1837; delegate to the State constitutional convention in 1833 and to the State Whig conventions in 1835 and 1843; unsuccessful candidate for election in 1836 to the Twenty-fifth Congress; elected as a Whig to the Twenty-sixth and Twenty-seventh Congresses (March 4, 1839-March 3, 1843); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1842 to the Twenty-eighth Congress; delegate to the Whig National Convention in 1844; elected to the Twenty-ninth, Thirtieth, and Thirty-first Congresses and served from March 4, 1845, until his resignation in 1850; chairman, Committee on Naval Affairs (Thirtieth Congress); appointed by President Fillmore as collector of the port of San Francisco, Calif., October 14, 1850, and served until October 1, 1852, when he resigned; returned to St. Simons Island, Ga.; again a member of the State senate in 1859; delegate to the Democratic National Convention at Baltimore in 1860; appointed a commissioner of Georgia in 1861 to visit Europe in the interest of trade, and was a commissioner of the Confederacy in Europe 1861-1863; died in Waresboro, Ware County, Ga., May 10, 1864; interment in the churchyard of Christ Church, Frederica, St. Simons Island, Ga.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: King, Thomas Butler. California. New York: W. Gowans, 1950.

------. Speech of the Hon. T. Butler King, of Georgia, on the Oregon question: delivered in the House of Representatives of the United States, February 9, 1846. Washington: Printed at the Office of the National Intelligencer, 1846
Steel, Edward M., Jr. T. Butler King of Georgia. Athens: University of Georgia Press, 1964.

researchRecord.name: Two official letters (March 20 and April 15, 1848) in the Jay family collection.
1835-1837, 1839; 0.05 cubic foot (1 folder).
researchRecord.description: The collection contains 8 letters of Thomas Butler King to his brother, Henry King, regarding family matters, crops, financial matters, and the Brunswick and Florida railroad.

researchRecord.name: In King-Wilder family papers, 1817-1946, 845 items.
researchRecord.description: Collection is chiefly personal papers with some letters pertaining to his political career. Unpublished finding aid in repository.

researchRecord.name: In File II Names
researchRecord.description: File is primarily incoming correspondence to the Governor of Georgia. Finding aid in repository.

recordLocation.name: Georgia Department of Archives and History

researchRecord.name: 1773-1868, 2003; 11.5 linear feet (ca. 4,000 items).
researchRecord.description: Collection contains correspondence and papers pertaining to his business and public activities, plantation management, family life, and Civil War. Finding aid is available online and in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the William Audley Couper papers, 1795-1955, 3.5 linear feet (ca. 1,700 items).
researchRecord.description: Persons represented include Thomas Butler King.

researchRecord.name: 1 item.
researchRecord.description: Testimonial signed by 172 prominent New Yorkers expressing appreciation of King's efforts in getting Mail Steamer Bill passed during the 1847 congressional session.

researchRecord.name: 1845-1851, 21 items.
researchRecord.description: Personal and business papers, including a clipping and a biographical sketch. Related papers are in Southern Historical Collection, University of North Carolina. Finding aid in repository.

recordLocation.name: Special Collections Department, Robert W. Woodruff Library

researchRecord.name: In the papers of William Gibbs McAdoo, 1823-1992, 12 boxes, 1 oversize folder, and 3 oversize volumes.
